Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Boolean Microgrid

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Boolean Microgrid (BM) emulates the Internet by supplying discrete power and discrete data over a network link that follows Boolean logic and is not continuous as in a conventional 60-Hz-ac or dc microgrid. BM is thus a highly integrated cyber-physical system (CPS) that features the convergence of control, communication and the physical plant. BM?s realization poses the following research challenges that we plan to address: a) what is the most efficient, economic, power-dense, and reliable way of integrating the distributed energy sources and loads to the BM, and the BM to the utility grid, using power-electronic interfaces for seamless and on-demand distributed power delivery? b) what is the control-communication mechanism that optimizes BM nodal and network control performances under conditions of varying power generation and load demand and communication-network throughput and reliability? Our unique approaches to address these research challenges will encompass novel mechanisms based on high-frequency-link power conversion, dynamic-pricing based optimal network capacity and resource utilization, event-triggered sampling and communication, and optimal switching-sequence control.
BM has the potential to influence next-generation systems including smart grid, vehicular microgrid, electric ships, military microgrid, electric aircraft, telecommunication systems, and residential, commercial, and critical-infrastructure (e.g., hospital) power systems. On the educational front, the proposed project will provide graduate- and post-graduate-level education to four researchers. Further, multiple undergraduate (including minority) students and middle-school students will be provided research/educational opportunities. The results of the research will be integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses at the collaborating universities including a dedicated course on CPS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A provisional patent protected approach for “sequential” co-transmission of high frequency (discretized) power and data signals (and packets) over a common high frequency pulsating voltage link is explored in this project and experimentally validated. This is in contrast to the conventional power line communication, where the power and data co-transmission is “simultaneous” and the high frequency data is injected on a slow scale power signal. The proposed sequential co-transmission avoids data corruption by temporally distributing power and data signals over a high frequency channel and limiting their overlap. A data transfer mechanism to realize the sequential co-transmission approach is outlined and experimentally validated. Simple transmitter and receiver circuits, synthesized without the use of any complex analog filtering circuitry and harmonic traps, as typically needed in conventional power line communication, are designed and a modified asynchronous serial communication interface protocol is implemented for ensuring the integrity of the transmitted data. The sequential high frequency power and data co-transmissions is experimentally validated using a closed loop distributed power converter network operating in switching frequency range of hundred kilo Hertz. In addition to the above outlined core synthesis, this project led to several other key novel innovations towards network scalability using event driven and self triggered communication relying on need based data transfer, and experimental validation of dc link capacitorless high frequency link power conversion systems.
